smell_analysis.justification: Every identified diagram (package, use-case, activity, state, class, and database diagrams) contains at least one central element (class/table/use case/state); none of the 14 diagrams is empty.

On the use-case diagram 'Arhetüüpide funktsionaalne allsüsteem', all listed use cases (e.g., 'Koosta arhetüüp', 'Muuda kinnitamata arhetüüpi', 'Esita arhetüüp') appear inside the system boundary and there is no unambiguous evidence of any use case being completely unconnected to actors; the text extraction does not show any use case explicitly lacking all actor associations, so this smell cannot be confirmed.

The use-case diagram does not contain two or more use cases whose names describe the same activity for the same actor; names like 'Koosta arhetüüp', 'Esita arhetüüp', 'Kinnita arhetüüp', 'Muuda kinnitamata arhetüüpi', and 'Muuda kinnitatud arhetüüpi' each describe distinct actions and are not simple synonyms for the same activity.

No package diagram shows multiple model elements with exactly the same primary element name within the same package; repeated classifier-type labels such as 'Klassifikaator' or 'Klassifikaatori tüüp' are treated as metadata and not separate model elements, and there is no clear case of two distinct elements with the same name in the same package.

In the database diagrams, repeated columns that might hold the same kind of value (such as various '*_id' or 'nimetus' columns) are either generic system fields or are linked by explicit foreign keys (for example, 'kasutaja_liik_kood', 'kasutusotstarve_kood', and various '**id' fields all participate in FK relationships), so there is no unambiguous case of denormalized redundant data stored in multiple tables without an FK connector.

Use-case names follow a consistent imperative-verb form such as 'Koosta arhetüüp', 'Muuda kinnitamata arhetüüpi', 'Kustuta arhetüüp', 'Lükka tagasi arhetüüp', 'Vaata kinnitatud arhetüüpe', 'Esita arhetüüp', and 'Kinnita arhetüüp'; there is no mixture of fundamentally different naming forms (e.g., noun-only names versus verb-phrase names).

In the state diagram 'Arhetüübi seisundidiagramm', all states ('Koostamisel', 'Esitatud', 'Kinnitatud', 'Tagasi lükatud', 'Kustutatud') have incoming transitions from either the initial state or another state (e.g., 'Tehnik / Muutja koostab arhetüübi /OP1' to 'Koostamisel', 'Tehnik esitab arhetüübi /OP2' to 'Esitatud', 'Muutja kinnitab arhetüübi /OP3' to 'Kinnitatud'), so no state is clearly unreachable.

In both activity diagrams ('Esitatud arhetüübi kinnitamise tegevusdiagramm' and 'Kinnitatud arhetüübi muutmise tegevusdiagramm stsenaariumid'), each action node such as 'Vaatab kõikide arhetüüpide nimekirja', 'Otsib kinnitamiseks arhetüüpi', 'Vaatab esitatud arhetüübi detaile', 'Kinnitab arhetüübi', 'Lükkab tagasi arhetüübi', 'Vaatab kinnitatud arhetüüpide nimekirja', 'Valib potentsiaalselt ebatäpsete andmetega kinnitatud arhetüübi', 'Teeb muudatusi arhetüübi andmetes' is connected by a flow from a preceding node; there is no action that is isolated or unreachable.

On the conceptual class diagrams, associations between classes (for example, between 'Arhetüüp', 'Hoone', and 'Isik' in both the 'Kontseptuaalne eskiismudel' and 'Arhetüüpide register' diagrams, and between 'Isik' and 'Kasutaja_liik' or 'Hoone' and 'Kasutusotstarve') explicitly show multiplicities such as '0..*', '1', or '0..1'. On the database diagrams, inter-table relationships are drawn as standard FK connectors (often annotated with «FK» and implied crow’s-foot style) and are explicitly exempt from this rule. There is no unambiguous UML-style relationship line between classes or tables that lacks multiplicity indicators at both ends.

The use-case diagram 'Arhetüüpide funktsionaalne allsüsteem' shows 10 distinct use cases ('Tuv asta kasutaja', 'Koosta arhetüüp', 'Muuda kinnitamata arhetüüpi', 'Kustuta arhetüüp', 'Lükka tagasi arhetüüp', 'Muuda kinnitatud arhetüüpi', 'Vaata kinnitatud arhetüüpe', 'Vaata kinnitamata arhetüüpe', 'Esita arhetüüp', 'Kinnita arhetüüp') on a single diagram, reaching the threshold of 10 central elements, so this size smell is present.

No class or table on any single class/database diagram has 6 or more distinct visible relationship lines: conceptual classes such as 'Arhetüüp', 'Hoone', and 'Isik' have at most around four or five associations on their respective diagrams, and database tables like 'Arhetuup', 'Isik', and 'Hoone' each participate in fewer than six separately drawn FK connector lines; there is no evidence of an element connected by 6 or more distinct lines.

The provided text extraction from the PDF does not include spatial information such as coordinates or distances between elements, and there is no explicit annotation indicating that any related elements are unusually far apart; without clear layout evidence, no distance-based layout smell can be confirmed, so this rule is not marked as violated.

All clearly action-like use-case and activity-node names begin with an active verb in Estonian (e.g., 'Koosta arhetüüp', 'Muuda kinnitamata arhetüüpi', 'Kustuta arhetüüp', 'Lükka tagasi arhetüübi', 'Vaata kinnitatud arhetüüpe', 'Vaatab kõikide arhetüüpide nimekirja', 'Otsib kinnitamiseks arhetüüpi', 'Kinnitab arhetüübi', 'Lükkab tagasi arhetüübi'); question-style labels such as 'Kas leidus?' and 'Kas jätkata?' correspond to decision nodes rather than actions. There is no unambiguous case where a use-case name or action node name fails to start with an active verb.

No class, table, attribute, or use-case name in the diagrams is three characters or shorter; names are longer identifiers such as 'Arhetüüp', 'Isik', 'Hoone', 'Kasutusotstarve', 'arhetuup_id', 'kasutajanimi', and 'korruste_arvu_alumine_piir', and there are no visible domain element names like 'id' or 'usr' used alone.

All class and table names that represent singular domain entities start with an uppercase letter and are singular, such as 'Arhetüüp', 'Hoone', 'Isik', 'Arhetuup', 'Kasutaja_liik', 'Kasutusotstarve', 'Arhetuubi_alamtuup', and 'Arhetuubi_seisundi_liik'; plural names are used only in register/package labels like 'Isikute register' or 'Hoonete register', which are domain registers and explicitly exempt from this rule.

Attribute and column names consistently start with lowercase letters (for example, 'nimetus', 'kood', 'kasutuselevõtu_aasta_alumine_piir', 'eesnimi', 'email', 'parool', 'ehitusalune_pindala', 'korterite_arv', 'arhetuup_id', 'hoone_id', 'kasutaja_liik_kood', 'arhetuubi_seisund_kood'); uppercase prefixes like 'PK*' or 'FK_' appear only in constraint or index names, not as attribute/column names, and are outside the scope of this rule.

Database tables that represent individual domain entities (e.g., 'Arhetuup', 'Isik', 'Hoone', 'Arhetuubi_alamtuup', 'Kasutusotstarve', 'Kasutaja_liik', 'Arhetuubi_seisundi_liik') are all singular; plural terms appear only in register names like 'Isikute register' or 'Hoonete register', which denote domain registers and are explicitly exempt from this rule.

Class, table, and attribute names do not use type-indicating prefixes or abbreviations such as 'tbl_', 'uc_', or 'strName'; the naming scheme is domain-oriented (e.g., 'Arhetuup', 'Isik', 'Hoone', 'arhetuup_id', 'kasutuselevotu_aasta_ulemine_piir') and the only visible prefixes of the form 'PK_', 'FK_', or 'IXFK_' occur in key and index identifiers, which are explicitly allowed exceptions.
